items.title: "pip-review -a" updates an package to newest version while the older version is required by other package.
items.body:
Got this error while running "pip-review -a":
ERROR: astroid 2.4.2 has requirement lazy-object-proxy==1.4.*, but you'll have lazy-object-proxy 1.5.0 which is incompatible.
And it still updated lazy-object-proxy to 1.5.0, which broke the dependency of astroid.

Can pip-review check the dependency first before updating?

items.title: Tryes to update pinned requirements
items.body:
Hi.
Reading change logs I found some points on that pip-review do not updates packages that are required by others. But it actually fails to handle this update case.

> pip-review -a
> ERROR: tensorflow 2.0.0 has requirement gast==0.2.2, but you'll have gast 0.3.3 which is incompatible.

Also tensorflow works with errors/warnings.  So then i need to manually do something with this package.

> tensorflow==2.0.0
> gast==0.2.2
> pip install tensorflow -U
> tensorflow==2.2.0rc2
> gast==0.3.3

I'm not sure how and where (guess in pip install) it fails but it does.

items.title: Show overall results and errors
items.body:
Hi.
How can I see overall results including errors? Something like this:

> Successfully updated 57/60 packages.
> Could not update 3 packages: tensorflow, radon, gitsome.

items.title: pip-review tries to update packages installed with `--user` at a root level
items.body: I'm trying to update packages installed with `pip install --user` so I ran `pip-review --user --auto` which correctly detects the right user level packages to upgrade, but then tries to install them globally to `/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/...`.

Doing `sudp pip3 install  pip-review` will also output to `/usr/local/bin/pip-review` breaking the the python2 version.

```
bash ~
$ sudo pip2 install pip-review
Collecting pip-review
  Using cached https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/92/a0/d978fd28bab000001304a29d560af69a755d9524bece3f6af7f3f1fcccca/pip_review-1.0-py2.py3-none-any.whl

Requirement already satisfied: packaging in /usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages (from pip-review)
Requirement already satisfied: pyparsing>=2.0.2 in /usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages (from packaging->pip-review)
```

items.title: Add a LICENSE.txt
items.body: The project is documented as being distributed under the BSD license. This is intended (both by Vincent Driessen and by myself), but no license file is included. This [appears to be necessary](https://packaging.python.org/tutorials/distributing-packages/#license-txt). So I'll add it sometime soon.

items.title: Implicit dependency on setuptools, possibly better to use packaging
items.body:
I just noticed that `pip_review.__main__` imports `parse_version` from `pkg_resources`, which is part of setuptools. Setuptools is not listed as a dependency in the `setup.py`, so technically, this is bug. However, it is not a severe one, as to my knowledge nobody has run into trouble yet by trying to run pip-review in an environment without setuptools.

We could just make setuptools an explicit dependency. However, we already explicitly rely on packaging, [which has a version parser as well](https://packaging.pypa.io/en/latest/version/). It might, in fact, be better than `pkg_resources.parse_version`.

I am planning to explore this. As always, that shouldn't stop others from stepping in.

items.title: tries to upgrade ipython to 6.0 on Python 2, which is impossible and never will be possible

milestone.title: Version 1.0
milestone.description: Planned to defer to `pip list -o` in order to find updates.

items.body:
Hello Guys,
`pip-preview` currently tries to upgrade Python 2  's ipython to 6.0, even though it's not available on python 2, and never will, as the jupyter/ipython devs have come out clearly saying they will never support python 2 on 6 and onwards.
 `pip list --outdated` accurately doesn't show ipython 6.0 for Python 2.

items.title: setuptools-specific features in setup.py break Travis build

milestone.title: Version 1.0
milestone.description: Planned to defer to `pip list -o` in order to find updates.

items.body:
In the latest release branch, I converted `setup.py` to use the proper notation for supported Python versions (ccf48c30) and platform-specific dependencies (47203ee3). Unfortunately, that [broke the Travis build](https://travis-ci.org/jgonggrijp/pip-review/builds/220136344). For some unclear reason that I need help with, these features cause the installation step to fail at `pip install .`. I do not see these errors if I run the tests locally with `tox`.

I tried updating pip (a29db746), but that [didn't help](https://travis-ci.org/jgonggrijp/pip-review/builds/220140481). I also tried ensuring that setuptools is installed (6e428696), but that [didn't make a difference](https://travis-ci.org/jgonggrijp/pip-review/builds/220142953), either. I decided to accept the broken Travis builds for now and release anyway ([0.5.3](https://github.com/jgonggrijp/pip-review/releases/tag/0.5.3)), because I felt reasonably certain that `pip-review` still installs and works, but the problem is unsolved.

If somebody knows how to solve this, help will be much appreciated.

items.title: Use subprocess.call([sys.executable, '-m', 'pip', ...]) to call pip

milestone.title: Version 1.0
milestone.description: Planned to defer to `pip list -o` in order to find updates.

items.body:
Do **not** use "`os.system('pip install {0}=={1}'.format(pkg, version))`".

Instead, I suggest doing as follows:
```python
import pip
pip.main(['install', '{0}=={1}'.format(pkg, version)])
```

Sorry for my poor English.

items.title: Reimplement pip-review on top of pip list --outdated

milestone.title: Version 1.0
milestone.description: Planned to defer to `pip list -o` in order to find updates.

items.body:
Instead of using `pip freeze` to get a list of installed packages and then running custom code to fetch the latest version from pypi.python.org, simply call `pip list --outdated` to get all the necessary information at once. Forward arguments like `--pre`, `--local` and `--user` directly to the call to `pip list --outdated`.

Will allow us to replace the `load_pkg_info`, `guess_pkg_name`, `get_pkg_info`, `latest_version`, `get_latest_versions` and `get_installed_pkgs` by a single short function that does the call to `pip list --outdated`.

Will resolve #6, #18, #21 and #27 at once.

After this change, pip-review will formally depend on pip>=1.3. This is the first version of pip that shipped with the `list` subcommand and the corresponding `--outdated` option.

items.title: pip-review does not find updates, pip list --outdated does

milestone.title: Version 1.0
milestone.description: Planned to defer to `pip list -o` in order to find updates.

items.body:
```
$ pip2 list --outdated                                                                                                                                                           
arrow (0.8.0) - Latest: 0.10.0 [sdist]
beets (1.3.19) - Latest: 1.4.1 [sdist]
cheat (2.1.26) - Latest: 2.1.27 [sdist]
Cython (0.25.1) - Latest: 0.25.2 [wheel]
[...]

$ pip-review
Everything up-to-date

$ python2 -m pip_review
Everything up-to-date

$ pip2 show pip_review                                                                                                                                                            
Name: pip-review
Version: 0.5
[...]
Location: /usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages
Requires: packaging

$ pip2 --version
pip 9.0.1 from /usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages (python 2.7)

$ uname -rs
Darwin 16.1.0
```

This happens with Python 2.7.12, the builtin version of macOS and with Python 3.6.0rc1 as well.

As a workaround I've used: `pip2 list --outdated|cut -d' ' -f1|xargs pip2 install --upgrade`.
If you want it to be interactive you could do something like `pip2 list --outdated|vipe|cut -d' ' -f1|xargs pip2 install --upgrade`.

items.title: [Bug] Can not run pip-review on Windows with Python 3
items.body:
### Summary

I can not run command `pip-review`.
### Expected behavior

I want automatically updates all my pip modules.
### Actual behavior

```
E:\Chocolatey>pip-review
"pip-review" не является внутренней или внешней
командой, исполняемой программой или пакетным файлом.
```
### Steps to reproduce

I read in [Stack Overflow answer](http://stackoverflow.com/a/16269635/5951529), what I can update all my pip modules use `pip-review`. I install `pip-review` — `pip install pip-review`, I restart my Windows → I run `pip-review`, but I get error.
### Environment

**Operating system and version:**
Windows 10.0.14393
**Python**
3.5.2
**Pip**
8.1.2
**Pip-review**
0.4

Thanks.

But it remains a wonder that dilemma (I am under ARM Archlinux).
$ pip-review
mysql-connector-python==2.0.4 is available (you have 2.1.3)

It's normal?

items.title: match available upgrade to compatibility with latest version of main tool?
items.body:
First, I think this is a great tool, thanks for rescuing it. My question arises as I look at upgrading to Django 1.9.1 from 1.7. Pip-review does not tell me if any of my dependencies, new or not, are compatible with Django 1.9.1. I'm thinking something like:

dependency x, new version, is compatible with Django x, latest version (or any other Python app)

I don't know if this is possible, or how difficult it would be to implement, but it sure would be a nice convenience. Call it a feature request more than an 'issue'. Let me know what you think, Thx.

items.title: Add --user switch

milestone.title: Version 1.0
milestone.description: Planned to defer to `pip list -o` in order to find updates.

items.body:
It would be great to have a "--user" switch, just like the one `pip` itself has.

See also pip-tools issue nvie/pip-tools#45.

items.title: Crashes with pip < 6.x
items.body:
``` pip-review
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/virtualenv/bin/pip-review", line 40, in <module>
    from pip._vendor.packaging import version as packaging_version
ImportError: No module named packaging
```

```
pip (1.5.4)
pip-review (0.4)
```

Using pip-tools==0.3.6 pip-review works fine with the same old version of pip so it looks like there was a regression after the fork.
